row.Text: See the accepted answer to my question on MSO: [link](http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/65216/what-differences-will-upgraded-se1-0-sites-have-compared-to-other-stackexchange/65220#65220)

Only being stuck in the sense that the build up and development of the site doesn't have the same feel as the other new 2.0 sites. Obviously we are blessed with a large community in place already which is great, but there is a certain excitement (maybe just me) in fleshing out all the details of the sites through the meta on the entirely new sites.

*That* I can agree with. I miss that new car smell, too; even if ultimately the missions is to get great answers to your questions, I miss watching the first people walking in the door. But it's a short-term "loss" and, hopefully, people will start to take ownership (meta) and *really* get to the task of building this site.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts. I have the same feelings about startups.com.
Agree 100%. We have a good community, it would be silly to ignore that.

I checked out the site out and WOW, you aren't kidding. The user @ http://startups.com/users/737/unknown-google can't get up and use the bathroom without asking the community about it. The look and feel and the user interaction with both onstartus.com and startups.com is about the same. It's interesting, then, that by tweaking the rules and starting with a particular user base, you can end up with such different end results. Is there any other difference I'm not accounting for?

@John: No, I think your analysis is about right. I think what shaped each community was the initial user base and the culture each created. Dharmesh and Jason started with a strong/competent user base (for many reasons), which established the culture and guidelines for the rest of us.

I am aware of it. And I would not attempt to brand a community with my name. On every page. Unless it was my personal blog. Setting aside what's fair to the previous owner, consider first the interests of the community and the effect it has on how the community is perceived as an unbiased source of startup owners. I'm not saying, "Bah! We don't need no Dharmesh!" Just make it subtle - the people for whom it actually matters know who donated the brand. I can't help but wonder - however false it may be - are we more concerned with crafting a community or getting more blog readers?
Thank you. Yes, English.SE seems to make more sense.

I think this question might be a little "intimidating". I know I tend to get overwhelmed when I see too much text and too many questions in one question. Maybe this should be split up into three separate questions? Especially since each one of these requires a lot of thought.

@Zuly Gonzalez: I considered making it three questions but I'm not really looking for "three answers," per se. The goal is to identify a "brand" the site with an elevator pitch and/or a tag line. The 1, 2, or 3 answers can work together. It really *is* one exercise.
Are you looking for feedback on your product? Or are you looking for research related feedback? Can you please elaborate?

Kelly: Welcome to the site, and thanks for sharing your thoughts! I'm happy to see that you are becoming an active member! I'm not sure I would consider it spam if the product promotion is wrapped in a more general startup related question. Especially if the question helps other community members, not just the poster. However, if it becomes a pattern, then I would consider it spam. Thoughts?
I'm looking for information on how people already handle part of their business in order to get a better picture of what sort of audience I need to target.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts! I agree that this is the way to go.
I would only add that it should deal with a startup.
@Robert - Would Stack Exchange consider expanding your classifieds section ala careers.stackoverlow.com to allow posting these sorts of requests (looking for partner etc.)?
@xiaohouzi79: Most definitely.
Perfect, thanks! Do we have access to the original proposal? It might be useful to post it, or portions of it.

Sure. It's still in Area 51: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/6243?phase=definition. It would be great if a cleaned-up version of the top 5(?) on- and off-topic questions were added to the FAQ. You now have the ability to edit the FAQ (see the `edit` link).

@Robert: It looks like the Area 51 proposal you linked to was started after this site was up and running. When you mentioned the original proposal, I assumed it was something Dharmesh and Jason created and submitted to the SE folks before hosting the 1.0 site. We don't have anything like that, do we?
@Zuly Gonzalez: No there is nothing like that.
OK, I didn't think so. I'll work on putting some of this in our FAQ.
This question belongs on the meta site http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/. I will move it there, with an answer
thanks..I think..
that is pretty funny.. lol
Yeah, I think it's kinda funny too :-) I'm not sure why that badge even exists. In my opinion, badges should be used to motivate positive behavior...this isn't necessarily a good thing :-)

I agree that it would be great to have either a resources FAQ or a direct "marketplace" for people trying to get together or who are looking for specific talent/skills. There are lots of competing sites for this, but frankly I found nothing that is a hands-down winner.

Also intimidating when one sees the Mottos thrown up there. I also disagree with the "recognize a good one" line - the only one I think that is recognizably good is the Nike one - the second one is grammatically incorrect, and the others are really nothing special - they are just noteworthy for the amount of money spent for us to recognize them.

I agree it would be good to have a formalized method to handle this - or even a place to point them to. the old Joel on Software discussion group seemed to have this sort of behavior - but that has turned into a bit of a ghost town. Other places are the paid sites by bob walsh and rob walling - but I hate to point people to those places as the only choices.

@Zuly, you seem to be very knowledgable on this site. We wanted to ask you what does it mean when we go to the site and get "invited" to go to something named "meta"...We are insanely intelligent with business apps (so we're told) but also the kind of guys that have the VCR clock still blinking ..lol.. could you give us some insight?
I see, so this was never in private beta.

No problem :-) The meta section of the site is used to ask questions about the site itself, whereas the "main" portion of the site is for asking questions about startups. For example, the question "Where can I get feedback on my businessplan?" can be asked on the main portion of the site, because it is a question related to startups. However, the question "Is it okay to submit my business plan here for review?" belongs on the meta portion of the site, because it is a question about the site's policy. Questions about badges, tags, what is on-topic vs off-topic, all belong on the meta portion.

You don't have to be invited to go to the meta portion of the site. All users have access to the meta site, and can ask and answer questions. I think it's important for all users to become involved with the meta questions because these discussions will shape the direction of the site. At the risk of sounding cheesy, it's your chance to have your voice heard.
as always you are very informative..thanks Zuly

Fair enough. But I would suggest it is placed in one question such as: "Please provide some good links for deciding how to divide equity in a startup" rather than questions like "How much equity should I give my cousin for doing the photocopying?". You will never see the end of this type of question otherwise.

While I agree with Martin that the site would get more exposure as a subdomain @ stackexchange, I don't think we are lacking enough in people that it matters terribly. It would be nice to see the site move, just like it would be nice to have steak tomorrow instead of pot roast, but I'm still going to go at the pot roast with gusto if that's what we have!

Thanks for the feedback and for the work you've put in with getting this site up and running. Shame to hear this meta site has low participation. There are a quite a few people willing to answer questions on the main site. I've been trying hard to ask a few questions here and get some involvement going.
I thought this was the original... http://onstartups.com/answers/tabid/87926/Default.aspx
What is wrong with that description?

The site has been running outside of SE for quite a while. You removed the old set of moderators without emailing them and the meta stuff is not really obvious. It is odd that you seem to want to see meta when Joel and Jeff initially fought against it for so long and I think (at least int he beginning) preferred NOT to have it. Is there really that much to say about this site in meta? Essentially it is a little odd to expect that a site that has been running from the beginning without an area51 and meta to act like ones that did come from area51. This community is well past that.

As John points out I think these are a special case of questions that are "sort of" on topic. As for subjective - I think much of the subject matter here IS subjective. It is certainly less objective than SO.

These types of questions are subjective, how much you pay someone depends on circumstance and answers can never reflect those circumstance. Our FAQ points to this post: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/ The point of focusing on questions with definitive answers is so people can learn. As mentioned in that link, this is not a message board. Think for a second if these types of questions improve our community, or is it just to benefit the asker?

To quote from that link: "… eventually the experts (i.e. people who are teaching you stuff) get drowned out and you are left with an experience that looks more like the magazine rack at a grocery store than a book shelf at Harvard. — Robert Scoble"

I am familiar with those FAQs. If we removed all the subjective questions from onstartups there would not be much left... I would also point out that there really only a handful of "experts" on this site right now. (I am NOT including myself in that) - and you deleted your comment.
I agree there is really no answer to the question - but the point is that just closing them will not decrease the frequency of the closings and the people will still have the same question.

@Tim - Yes, I deleted my comment. One too many. OK, I agree with you about not being much left if we go culling all subjective questions. But, I do think something should be done with "How long is a piece of string" type questions. Either through editing or moderation. Maybe one of us could come up with a good quality all encompassing question, close the others as duplicates pointing to that question. There must be a good answer to this problem.

I was hoping to get feedback from Robert or one of the other SE guys, that's why I tagged it as feature-request. I can see this as an important part of the overall experience, but not really part of the Q&A side. Thanks for your feedback.

I don't see how they harm the community. The comments are useful to anyone interested in critiques and analysis of web sites. Blatant attempts to get traffic of course are counter to the sites purpose and should be closed.

@Tim: I disagree. I think the critiques are specific to an individual website, and therefore are only useful to the OP. General comments about website design are fine, and do help the community, but when someone posts a link to their site and asks for feedback it is usually very specific. I personally don't get any benefit out of those questions.

@Tim: (Cont.) They harm the community because if one person does it, then everyone is going to start doing it. Next thing you know, that's all you'll see on the site. That'll discourage new users to join, and probably cause some old time users to leave the site (I would). And as xiaohouzi79 pointed out, most of these questions are coming from people with 1 rep. What are the chances these people will actually come back and contribute to the community? Very little - they are only interested in getting feedback, not becoming involved in the community.

@Tim: (Cont.) But I do think it's a good idea to dedicate a separate portion of the site to these questions. I understand that people have these concerns (I know I do - my website looks like crap right now), and I think it would be great if we could help them out. I just don't think those questions belong on the main site because they will end up drowning out the real startup/business questions. Do you think is an acceptable solution?

@xiaohouzi79: I think Robert is the only SE guy participating on this site right now, but I'm sure he can pass this along to them. However, I don't think they'll do this for us unless we get more feedback from other community members on this issue. As of right now, Tim and I are the only ones who have expressed an opinion. We need to get more participation over here.

@Tim: Aw, come on, that's not fair. The discussion against "meta talk" was almost 1-1/2 years ago (an eternity on the Internet), before there was even an explicit meta site (http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/06/cmon-get-meta/). Now *every* site has their own dedicated meta. If this site is "well past" meta, that's okay. That's how most communities talk to us (and each other) about issues like promotions and feature requests and community-building issues in general. Most communities really want and appreciate those activities and that level of attention. So meta is here if you need it.
Yep - that was a useless comment. SOrry

@Zuly - interesting. I don't see how it is different from all the other "here is my problem" questions that are specific to one company that are all over onstartups. People certainly can ignore those requests. Frankly I don't like those either. I guess we should just leave it to rob walling and bob walsh. Maybe Onstartups just isn't the success it could have had. Oh well.

@Tim: presumably, other questions relating to "how do I do X" are relevant to more than the person asking. Whereas "give me feedback on my project" won't be. Of course, if you read tens of those, you would eventually learn something (have a better home page, use an action button, etc.). But that doesn't sound like the right way to share that knowledge. But I'd be ok with questions such as "How do I improve the conversion rate on my site, here's the URL". What do you think?

I have found plenty of useful bits when reading comments on web sites over at JoS. I agree in general that those are not as good as more generic questions, but I don't think they have value ONLY for the OP.
+1 This is a great idea and will help not just with keeping the main site clean, but also having some more relevant questions on the meta site.
@Zuly - Is there anything we can do to assist in the process? e.g. flagging any of the old 1.0 meta questions for moderator attention
Also, as a good habit, if you find yourself answering a question this usually means it is worthy of an up-vote.

@xiaohouzi79: I can't think of anything right now. Finding the questions should be fairly easy, because they are tagged with the meta tag. If you happen to find a question that isn't tagged meta, you can go ahead and flag it, otherwise it isn't necessary. Thanks for offering though! I'm going to give it another day or two before moving the questions to give people a chance to share any concerns they may have.

It's not something we can change really, it is a design choice made by the Stack Overflow dev team. You can read the rationale here: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/03/the-value-of-downvoting-or-how-hacker-news-gets-it-wrong/ I'm not a fan of it either, but it does work -- and you avoid most of the rep loss by using the "flag as spam" and "vote to close" where appropriate, as the others have pointed out.
Are you able to query based on [meta] for the maint?
If i want to start my business in say, Japan, and ask where i can stay to start my startup, this will make it business related. So where is the difference? I still disagree with you %100.

Besides that, you don't get the idea behind my thoughts. This site already LACKS the users. If you continue to treat users like that, it will lose even more users. No one asked me to modify or correct my question. I also checked the faq, it does in no way state that such a question, somehow related to business and startups, can't be asked. See? Though you typed in a longer fashion, the admin still FAILED and you to. That's it.

Robert is providing accurate feedback about the disposition of your question. Also if you believe there isn't enough users then there isn't enough people to give your question a chance to be answered. The reaction to the closing though is out of line. It is just the removal of a question not the distruction of your buisness.
Try a local university with x pats from Japan. They may have better thoughts on your original question.
@John: What do you mean by "maint"?
maintenance of the site.
I'm not sure I understand your question. My plan is to search for all questions with the meta tag. This isn't just for site maintenance - any user can do this search. Does that answer your question?
To clarify, the bottom right corner of the entire page, not the question itself.
Excellent question - thoughtfully articulated - thanks!
It looks like someone is volunteering for moderator responsibility...
Haha, you're the one with the Enthusiast badge, Tim. ;-) But yeah, if giving more users moderation powers is a solution, that sounds good to me.
+1 to the notion of spreading the workload around, by appointing some community moderators. I hereby nominate *everyone* in the first column of the "Users" page. :-D

Sorry if I didn't make it clear (editing now), by "marked as spam" I meant flagged. Voting down *is* good though, since it prevents these questions from being displayed on & getting more attention on many of the site pages.
Vote down or flag as spam enough times by X # of users and the site should automatically delete it.

Thanks for responding Dharmesh! It looks like in the comments here, Jesper has specifically said he'd be willing to moderate, I would be too, and Jesper's suggestion of taking a look at the first column of users would definitely find you some other active enough people it'd be worth asking if they'd like to pitch in.

as an aside to my answer, whenever I find something on a site that doesn't make sense I always search at http://meta.stackoverflow.com This is the original meta site that all other meta sites are based on and it has a huge community that spends all day discussing the way StackExchange sites work. If there is any issue it's likely they've spotted it first, no matter how trivial.

Dear John, what i try to underline is, there are better ways to improve a question, even if it might be wrong. If you simply cut it away as deleted/closed, the asker hasn't even a chance to fix the question. Can you understand that?
This is correct. Users who have never visited meta will not have an account on meta.answers.onstartups.com. Thank you for answering.

Keep in mind that "closing" is not the same as "deleting." I think the very *premise* of the question is off topic but, if you believe you can fix the question, then fix it. People can vote to re-open it. It happens all the time. That's the way these sites work.
Yep answered. I was thinking like a db function but obviously I'm over thinking. Thanks

Thanks! I suspected it had something to do with the software not seeing the user's account. But I was confused because I knew that at least some of those accounts were still active (on the parent site). I completely forgot that you have to visit the meta site in order for your profile to be seen on the meta. Makes sense now. I guess I will continue with the migration.

Very true! To answer some of the below: We can't control the fact that you need 15 rep to upvote, which sucks.
Therefore, AT LEAST FOR NOW, those of you who CAN upvote SHOULD, and ESPECIALLY when you see someone with less than 15 rep who makes a reasonable point.
Eventually we won't need special consideration, but this is a bootstrapping problem.
Thanks all!
Another thing: Even we admins/moderators are still limited to 30 votes per 24 hours. Otherwise I would just fix this myself! :-/
+1 for... no good reason other than to get you closer to 15 ;-)
thanks, now I can post comments too :D

I think the 15pt rep to vote is a great idea. It's a barrier to entry to prevent spam ... but it'd be nice if you could disable it until you started getting a majority of users with enough rep to vote.
Done! Vote away ...
+1, and *now* it's done. :-) I'm http://stackoverflow.com/users/84416/basicallymoney-com
and with my awesome 21 rep I'm off to vote... thanks!!
Ask and you shall receive. I gave you one already.
Thanks, I appreciate it.
It's appropriate, and +1! I just edited it to add our usual "meta" to the title and tags to mark it as such.
I will add that we don't control the software at all, so you have a better chance of getting what you want by posting here: http://meta.stackexchange.com/

The first time I logged in here I went to my Yahoo! OpenID thinggy and came back and posted (a relevant) question but... It was "unknown (yahoo)" or something for I didn't know I had to configure other things: I figured out my "Open ID" would be automagically my First Name/Family from my Yahoo! account (I was wrong but hey ;)
People will usually change it to the proper name once they are comfortable with the site. That's my personal experience.

The openID point is good (although I thought I remember them (Joel/Jeff) saying that they were going to introduce regular username/password logins for stackexchange sites. My point is that even for people who go to the trouble of registering, then then don't bother to enter any information.
The gravatar is actually based on the email address you have registered, not the openid used for logging in. Perhaps there's an error in your email address...
Denis, thank you! You are right!
Good question, I was going to ask for feedback on my new app but was unsure if was proper 'netiquette' here.
Hi Jeffepp, thanks for the comment :-)
@Jeffepp , post a question about your site. BTW- you need to mention affiliate program manager at the top of your site. It took some time to figure that out.
@Jeff Oresik - thanks! I have been looking to change some elements to effectively market our software. Will ask my question, waiting to push some updates live late tonight

Hi Susan, thank you for your answer. I'm a newcomer in this site and in the entrepreneurial world. In fact I'm building the basis before starting up so I hope I'll be an active user in the very next months :-)
This is a great suggestion and I'll apply it. Thank you Jeff.
Thank you Jesper for the detailed explanation. I'll try to be as less as noisy as possible. :-)
+1 for startuptodo.com, I have never heard of it and will definitely give it a try - thanks!

@Jeffepp: That's a very reasonable viewpoint, but I just still don't agree. I don't question that it is nice for the startup founder to go here and get reviews. What then remains to be seen is how many of the readers and contributors here who feel that announcements and reviews are in the way (as I would), and how many readers + contributors who like them (or at least are not bothered by them).

@Jesper: I will defer to your reputation points :) This is why I have not mentioned anything yet, even though I do think it would be beneficial to the community and obviously myself. As a contributor, I find said posts more interesting that the usual "how do I make money" questions with little to no detail about the product...

@Jeffepp: I don't think you should defer to my rep points; they relate to other, older answers. As I count it right now, there are 4 votes against (my own post + 3 upvotes), and 7 fairly positive (4 completely positive on Susan Jones' post, and 3 conditionally in favor on Jeff's post).
I guess, I think the disclaimer is lame. Now that I think of it, when I do answer a legal question, I qualify this by saying, "but you should ask an attorney."
It's not lame if one is a lawyer.
+1 on the last paragraph. You beat me to it :D

+1 - I thought about you, and I believe there is another lawyer that answers here, and in the case of you two a disclaimer makes sense, but for someone like me it would be pointless. I guess, if you are licensed in any area, and you give an answer in that area, then a disclaimer may be needed. So, a CPA giving out tax answers here should probably also have a disclaimer.
Thanks Dana. Excellent answer.

Found a related question on the other site... decided to cross post... hmmm, am I asking for trouble here?
http://startups.com/questions/4175/meta-gravatar-issue-many-users-with-same-icon
The link for the OnStartups discount is *right there* in the post.
If you need to make a business trip, FOR opening a business, then you need living space, and this is the place for asking a question like that.

We have discussed creating a separate portion of the site to address these questions, but we haven't received any feedback from the community on this. See this question http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/questions/41/what-to-do-with-feedback-on-my-site-type-questions What do you think about that suggestion? We would like to get your thoughts on this.
This should be tagged [meta]. But, I can't tag questions.
Answers to startup questions, generally depend on your current situation, thus are subjective by definition.
+1 - good way to address how to answer

Have a look at the following older discussion. It's not a 100% direct match to your question, but it has some overlap and can perhaps be inspirational: http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/12497/meta-is-advertising-updates-allowed-here
My reasoning for posting a survey was that is was a more structure way of asking questions, is this not the case?
+1 I agree. Benefit to site. Q & A style. Outside material used as ref only.
GReat answer thanks Jesper

I like the specific questions. I like to feel that I can help an individual startup with their real problems, not just wax theoritic on general startup advice (the type you can find on any blog/startup article site online). The whole point of the conversation Q&A format is, imo, to give a specific answer that benefits the asker and future readers. So my question for Jesper is how do you know what will be useful to future readers? I think you can assume things, but you may not be correct that someone else isn't searching for that same problem/answer. Hard to say what is useful for others.
+1 I hadn't gotten around to doing this either, mostly because I hadn't taken the time to learn how.
Thanks for your help, Steve
Thank you very much!
We should have a rate my startup section... where you can review a startup, (internet) and give advice on business model, advice, etc. Sort of like a community business coach. Hot or Not ! :)
+1, lovely response. :-)

@Herr Kaleun: You take the view that if a given issue *comes up in the context* of a startup, then it is on topic for this site. Taken to the extreme, that would mean that *anything* could be on topic for this site, as anything can somehow be loosely associated with business. Clearly, as site that has *anything* as its focus has no focus, and will suffer. So a certain balance has to be struck, and a decision taken between on- and off-topic. For what it's worth, you're not the first to believe that anything related to startups should be on topic here. :-)

If I need to make a business trip, for opening a business, then I need a suitcase, clothing, shoes, and travel documents. Is Onstartups the appropriate place to discuss what clothing to buy? Should we encourage questions on the best suitcase? Or are those questions so unrelated to the basic premise of Onstartups that their presence trivializes the entre site?
This is the kind of question that the ASP handles all the time. But you have to be a member there ($100 / yr) to get their feedback.
THANK YOU. I've been full time on a start up since September and this site has been the single most valuable resource. It's the quality - not the # of members or # of questions! THANKS!
I second Civil's comment. I think this site has been a valuable resource for many of us. Thanks for keeping it alive.

You're exactly right - the QUALITY of the dialogue here is generally excellent. I honestly don't even bother ever looking at Startups.com any more - it's got way too much garbage and clutter. Answers.OnStartups is a much better environment. One metric here might be how many top rated members are in each community - my guess is that Answers.OnStartups would have some excellent metrics in terms of frequency of posts and ratings of members.
Perhaps someone could write a Firefox plugin that would add new capabilities. :)

I like the idea of them having defs. I suggest possibly having defs added when tags are put in. Helps us consistenly force us to think through what audiance are we asking and why. Some of the popular tags are popular like startup because that's why we are here but it is really an echo of the site.
Good point John. It's actually hard to tag stuff, at least for me. Defs are good because it will give the author some ability to focus on what the question is really about.
I know. But am I allowed or is it against the rules?
I'm pretty sure no is going to arrest you for that :) I don't think there is rule for it but people doing it for free anyway why would you pay?
Because it would mean that I could ask questions that nobody would answer without money. For example, "Provide me with a list of companies and their marketshare in market X".
I see, I think you can try but there are specific websites for that task look for crowdsourcing websites, I'm sure you'll find good websites just designed for what you need.

I have tried lots of them, but I believe that the people attracted by the reputation model at OnStartups are the right people for doing all sorts of jobs. The people attracted by the pure for-profit websites, often do not have any pride in their work
Have you looked at http://uclue.com ? some pretty qualified researchers there...

I like the idea of offering advice here for free. Once in awhile, people will contact me via the details I have in my profile and we work together in a more traditional setting. I'm an attorney that has worked with startups for 15 years and this is how I like to give back. You could frame your question, "Can anyone provide me with a list of companies with X marketshare for a reasonable fee?"
Hmm, that isn't a question. This is not a message board, this is a place to ask questions and get answers.

I remember when StackOverflow, the very first of these sites, was in beta - people were going crazy moderating things in very inconsistent ways. And it is sad - people basically start to think they somehow have better insight into things, and that their opinion is correct while yours is wrong, etc. and they decide to push their own agendas or ways of looking at things.
Thanks, shall do - more entries are still coming in, but once they slow down, I'll dig through the analysis and doc it all up for posting.
By the way, I also filled it out before posting my initial answer! :)
+1 for "Down-voting ... should give you pause." This prevents malicious random downvoting.
Thanks for the helping hand Bob!
Is this the Royal We?
We, a group of us use the board. At times we discuss some topics and try to help. WE dont lways type at times it maybe ME, although at times when we are not using our Wii others may help.
WE hope this was helpful...lol...have a great WEekend!
not at all Ms Zuly..I go to my bookmark, site comes up..I comment and voila??? I dunno...and thanks for migrating me.. :)
I've also had issues on some SE sites for the first login or so. Then it seems to work ok
I do not know if it is a "issue" I just found it odd that we can never use the meta site...
@XS Direct: Yes, it is an issue. What you are seeing is definitely not normal behavior of the website. Try logging out of the whole site, and then logging back in. Let me know if that works.
Agree. Perhaps user more engagement and moderation would help?
typically the response to that is to put in a comment ask "why the down-vote". You are then likely to get a sympathy up vote.
This site has apparently plateaued. Every now and then there is an influx of good questions, but it seems stagnant.
Don't get it wrong - I'm not saying there's anything wrong with it, I just wanted to know. Thanks!

There are actually a number of benefits: It gives karam to new users which allows them to do things like down vote and I don't know exactly what. Also, up voting a question makes it "active" and bumps it to the top in the list of active questions.
@ripper: I didn't get the impression you were criticizing it, but I can see how my initial wording could have given that impression. I rephrased my answer to be a bit softer.

@Jeff Atwood, I appreciate all the dialog you are willing to have here. What is the rationale behind it "appearing 50% of the time, with decreasing frequency as you gain reputation"? First off, 50% makes the process seem capricious and unreliable. If the assumption is I should "know" the link is there by now, this requires me to be mindful each time to post it out into the world. I don't think stackexchange reputation makes someone any more mindful than they were before. Finally, character length is arguably not a good indicator of content value.
Wow, that's really not obvious!! Some usability improvements would be good to see.

@ken "There is a strong correlation between comment quality and length" -- Paul Graham. See http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/01/how-to-say-thanks-in-an-answer/ and FWIW I totally agree with him. As far as the randomness goes, it's like a blinking light for cyclists; more visible than a constant light and certainly less pattern blindness where you stop seeing it because it is always there.

@Jeff Atwood, I would reference another elegant voice who speaks for brevity. See http://zenhabits.net/snore/ While there is often unmistakably the coincidence of poor quality and brevity, it should not be misinterpreted as correlation.

@Jeff Atwood, you make a good point about pattern blindness, I am just not sure that reducing the frequency of the message is the answer. I think we should instead be looking for improved effectiveness, not just less of something that is not proving to be effective enough.

I'd like to also add, that as far as I know, they were **PAYING** customers of StackExchange before SE changed their business model. So yanking the rug out from under their feet would've been a little on the sleazy side. I believe this was actually mentioned in one of the SO podcasts.

What is the follow up from the developers to the idea -- confirmation of what has been or hasn't been implemented?

[feature-requests] are typically tagged [status-completed] when implemented, or [status-denied] if they cannot (or will not) be implemented due to some technical or philosophical issue. But there's a large middle class of feature requests that may not be implemented on sight but not rejected outright, either. For those, sometimes it's just knowing that you had a voice and offered a useful suggestion to improve the site. It's not always possible to implement everyone's requests and each suggestion has to be taken in stride. It's nice to have a forum like this to even discuss the issue.

In your example, the author actually *is* a lawyer... For why lawyers often add - *must* add - such disclaimers, see: [Do I need to add a disclaimer when I answer a question on this forum?](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/questions/113/do-i-need-to-add-a-disclaimer-when-i-answer-a-question-on-this-forum). Note that if you aren't a lawyer, you don't *need* a disclaimer; if someone follows your (bad) advice and (something bad happens), you're not liable (I don't think; IANAL)... Including one anyway is more of a courtesy to / sanity check for the reader.

BTW, this is very similar to a previous feature-request: [Protecting users on the legal-advice front](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/questions/225/protecting-users-on-the-legal-advice-front) - you should read the answer there as well.

Sometimes there are a string of comments that build on each other. Deleting one in the middle could cause even more confusion.
Also, I must push back against the statement "comments are rather disposable by nature". They are a critical part of the conversation.

@Kenneth: that's... kinda irrelevant. Anyone participating in a conversation can delete their portions of it at any time, moderators can wipe the entire conversation without a trace, there's no revision history... In short, the *essential nature* of comments is that of transient interaction, which stands in sharp contrast to information contained in questions and answers (which is quite difficult to ever expunge completely).
@Shog9, what you are describing is the transience of how comments are treated, not any intrinsic transcience. I am suggesting that we fix this treatment.

@Kenneth: to the contrary, the transience is inherent in how commenting is implemented, *built into the system itself*. Please see the links I added to the answer for two lengthy discussion on this. There are some good arguments both ways, but the key reasoning behind the current behavior is simple: comments are kept simple to *discourage* extended discussion - these sites are intended for questions and answers; if you want to discuss, go to chat.

Ok @Shog9, your edited answer provides some clarity on your position. I guess what this all boils down to is that the present implementation has flaws and I haven't offered a better solution as of yet.

Yes, I wouldn't try to answer that question, because after reading the first two paragraphs, I still haven't found an actual question. My advice: put a summarized question upfront, then give details and context.

But that would be a different question. What I was interested in was the sequencing of the steps -- not whether or not each individual step was or wasn't needed. There are an infinate number of potential permutations to most questions on here- - because they have to do with an individuals perception of what would be best. But just like no one would recommend developing a "life plan" after raising the money-- the number of permutations is limited by the practical experience of the participants.

For example there was a series of questions about the cost of nice office space in various locations -- the very definition of "nice" has an unlimited number of permutations based on the person's business, goal of the office space, values of the business, values of the entrepreneur. The answer has as many questions as their are office rates - -as each location might be "nice" and a good match for a particular business. And those questions resulted (for a variety of reasons) in some of the biggest "views" for questions on the site.

Can anyone cite an example of a case where an ex-employer sued/won/etc a dispute with an employee. I am not talking about outright theft, but rather legitimate business built outside of the day job.

I don't raise the question to dismiss your argument, rather I am curious as I see this brought up a lot but have never heard of a case where an employer actually pursued it and "won". (Again, with the caveat that the employee did not use IP from the day job)

What that site talks about doesn't apply to me. My business and day job company are different and unrelated. Second, where's the proof? Example, code in a paint shop has no relation to code for an eCommerce site. What you do outside of work is your own business.
Third, don't announce to ANYONE at work what you do. Never mention ANYTHING that can be used against you in the future. Your friend co-worker might turn against you and spill the beans when things go sour.
If your day job company has 0 knowledge, what can they do? I am a contractor and move a lot. Just be very cautious.

What I do is not patentable. No secret IP is involved. Any junior developer can do what I do. The idea you're working on is what matters.
Litigation happens when you compete with your employer and you are using the same code you developed at company time and payroll. That's a different story. But if you create some site, say, making money from affiliate marketing, I am sure it's OK.

@Tony - unfortunately some of your assertions are not correct. Many companies have clauses in the employment contracts stating that their employers' work is theirs - even if done "After hours" or on personal computers. I have no idea if this is enforceable and I agree it is outrageous, but just having an opinion about it is not useful. Note also that while it may not apply to your circumstance Rich was trying to help others to recognize a risk.

@Tim - In California, it is illegal for a company to have such a clause in their employment contract. What you do on your own time, with your own materials is your property unless you steal company secrets to do it. This varies from state to state, so you need to look up your states laws.
@Tim. I have worked at many companies and I have never seen such clause. If I ever see one, I will tell them "I am not interested" and before I leave, I will ask them why they have such a clause.
@everyone AS a counterpoint to my counterpoint: Check out Jason Cohen's opinion, from a guy that has definitely been there. http://blog.asmartbear.com/starting-up-while-employed-admit-it.html
interesting, but not what I was looking for. I am looking more for a case where a person started a company, not left for competitor AND a case where there was no conflict of interest/competition.

It's going to be hard to find such a case, if it even exists. If your business is an online application, how is your current employer going to get hold of your server side application which is not visible to the public? This is not the case of a desktop application where they downloaded it, reverse engineered it, compared its code with what they have, found too many similarities and made a case and filed a lawsuit. It's nothing like Novel Unix vs SCO Unix. My ideas have 0 threat to previous, current and future companies. Just make sure you don't work for a company that's very similar to yours.
by saying no to distractions, tv, etc... It's a matter of priorities and sacrifice.

I don't work at demanding companies. I love coding and whether I do it at work or at home, I am having fun. This is very important that you actually enjoy your work, otherwise you will feel burnt out. I rarely watch TV. Coding without any pressure actually relaxes me!

I personally love my work, so I'm happy to code away at my startup during my free time on nights and weekends after spending 8 hours mon-fri programming. It helps that I use two different languages (sometimes up to four) between work and my personal projects, so I don't feel like I'm doing the same thing for 13 hours a day.

Everything is not universally true. However it's also very possible. There are tens if not hundreds of thousands of open source, freeware and shareware software which are developed by people who keep a steady full time job. Some of these people's day job has nothing to do with software development. So if these people can do it, you can. I am in my forties. This means I have enough experience to execute and code cleanly than someone in his twenties. My mind is clear and focused. I don't have to chase girls, date, drink, explore the world & travel and all the other distracting activities.
Plus the skills I learn from working on my business can be applied at my work (and vice versa). My employers are too keen in paying for my continuous training and education.
It will be using the usual online marketing tactics. Adwords, joining forums, blogs, tweets which are about the same services I offer. Use a sig which points to your site.

IMHO, there are too many low-quality questions lately, such as umpteenth question about equity split. I think the FAQ & question closure guidelines need to be updated.

@Joel, I certainly meant no offense and I appreciate you are giving rather than taking at this forum. You said: "I consider startups to be tech or software related businesses." Is that not your personal position? You note that the FAQ does not take that position. You then asked: "...can the FAQ be updated." Can you see why I would have read that as you want the FAQ to be changed to match your personal position?

I agree with you about the low quality questions. I'm hoping that this contest will be the first step in improving that issue. I also agree with you on the equity split questions. Ideally, we should be closing them as duplicates, unless there is something really unique in a particular question. We discussed that a while back, and made some progress on it, but I don't think we're doing as good of a job as we should be. See [this question](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/questions/577) and [this answer and related comments](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/588) for some background on that

Or perhaps it should be made useful to the non-tech startup as the charter implies. How will that be so if we treat non-tech startups as redheaded stepchildren, dismissing or, even worse, downvoting or closing their questions?

If you see a repetitive equity question please vote to close as a duplicate of [this canonical Q&A](http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/27858/how-to-divide-up-your-companys-equity). That helps the mods and others make a decision on whether to close it.

The thing about equity splits is that almost all situations are unique. However, they're also very similar and asking yet another question about it doesn't add to the community. The problem is that it's hard to say which previous question fits this situation best.

@Joel, I believe there are a lot of people who would like this to be a "tech only" startup forum. However that is not what it was originally designed to be. I believe the reason this forum is struggling is that it is being condescending toward the people who don't also find Stack Exchange useful. That means we will only ever have a subset of Stack Exchange users here if we keep up this attitude. That is too small a pool for this forum to survive.

I don't know how you "make" something useful to a new audience when it already has a current focus that makes it a go-to place for a certain audience. What makes OnStartup a go-to place is the crowd that has already gathered here. I think among the possible choices, changing the FAQ would be the best choice here.

You make it useful by not actively making it useless in the ways I (and you, actually) described above. I am not dissing the tech startup crowd, I have been actively in it myself for decades. What I am pointing out is the non-tech crowd has attempted to come here and we are actively drive them away. What can we possibly gain from such an exclusionary attitude?

I understand. And that's exactly why we're in this predicament. The way I see it, the little details will be different (e.g. number of founders), but the guiding principles will usually always be the same (e.g. if everyone puts equal work, everyone gets equal share). That's where Jarie's canonical Q&A comes in handy. Take a look at it, it's very comprehensive. I think the subject of equity is within the scope of this site, so I wouldn't ban all equity questions, but I do think we need to reduce the number of them. But we're getting off-topic here; post a Q if you want to cont the discussion.

^ Absolutely nothing, and I do see your point. Question - what could be done as a check and balance to prevent this kind of turf protection behavior? It would appear that certain negative behaviors need to be muzzled. The problem is that those defending their techie discussion turf may otherwise have high ratings and therefore the power to effectively push out non tech participants. The way Exchange appears to work is that the community is indeed allowed to vote down even when it's against the FAQ. Thoughts?

@Kenneth, I can understand how you saw it that way, but I assure you it wasn't my intention. I had assumed the site was for tech startups, based on my interpretation of a "startup". It's not that I want it to be for that, it makes no difference to me if all businesses use it, in fact I am quite interested in all businesses. The reason for this question was that I downvoted a question that wasn't tech and someone commented that it didn't have to be tech. I then read the faq and saw there was no mention of tech, and just wanted to check the intention so I can moderate appropriately.

@Kenneth, your comment of " that is not what it was originally designed to be" is exactly the answer I came looking for. Based on all discussions since I posted this question I can see it is not for tech only, I will moderate accordingly. I also think it would be worth updating the FAQ to clarify this point, as perhaps there are others that confuse this like I do.

My question was more on the fact that people here talk about "developing software products" and not so much "using software to support/launch an innovative business model". Examples that come to mind are companies like Amazon or NetFlix, which have created new business models based on the web, and had to come up with software solutions (heavy load transactional and collaborative websites) that could support their business model to make it work and scale.

You make a good point Jacob. Dario mentioned there is not much room left for innovation, but I don't think that is true (nor ever will). Look at google: when they started out the industry said there was nothing else to do with search engines... wrong! Google solved an old problem in a new way and look where they are now! And you don't need to create a new product. Dell didn't "invent" a new PC, they just changed the way they were assembles, distributed and sold (changed the business model).
Do you guys agree?

Correct. To complete the answer, the original author is allowed to copy it, reformat it, without attribution. The rest of the world must follow the terms of the creative commons license.

To be clear, since you created the content, YOU have the copyright with it (and technically can do whatever you want with that particular content you contributed). However, SE Inc has a license to that content, and it is also licensed under Creative Commons to be used by anyone else provided they follow attribution.

@blunders We always have the option of changing our policies in the future. But, saying "let's just do what we want and not put any thought into establishing our current polices, because we can change our minds later" is not a smart strategy. There's a big risk with taking that approach. A few weeks ago SO had a huge uprising where several longtime users threatened to stop participating because of this reason. After some policy changes, certain Qs that were at one point allowed became off-topic. Some of these Qs had been around for years and had gathered hundreds of upvotes and many answers.

(Cont.) When the Qs were removed from SO, all hell broke loose. We would be foolish to ignore that. Removing content is controversial, so it's always best to try to get it right the first time around. It's our duty to take our policies seriously, and make a good faith effort to come to a solution that is in the best interest of the community based on the information we currently have available. At times we'll make mistakes, and we'll refine our policies as the site evolves, but that doesn't excuse carelessness.

@blunders As far as this being an issue based on feelings only, well that is not true. This is a site policy issue. People will have different opinions on what should be on-topic. Our job is to decide where we draw the line. "Anything that happens to vaguely come up during the course of doing business" is not an appropriate scope for this site. Otherwise questions like what is the best toilet paper to buy for my startup, or [finding a hotel for business travel](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/questions/69), would also be on-topic.
@TimJ I happen to agree with you, but I'm open to changing my mind if there is a strong case for allowing them.

And even if Tim went through the trouble of finding them, it would be useless because you cannot view them. Re Qs getting upvotes, although we should consider it, voting is a [rough measure](http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#reputation). We've removed Qs with more upvotes than the ones we're discussing. You only need 15 rep to upvote, so users will vote w/o knowing our policies.

However, I disagree that market research is only relevant to large established companies. By *general* I mean Qs that are helpful to a large audience.

I agree with your assessment of on-topic, but believe you are mis-assessing localization. Upvotes do not mean "this helped me" they mean "this i a good question" (or "this is a good answer"). And answers don't mean it helped either, they mean "Here's how to solve this problem". Upvotes might even mean "I thought this was interesting" or "I'm having a good day". Overlocalization, upvotes, and helpfulness are orthogonal. Lots of *page views* is a better indicator of helpfulness, but even that's not a great metric.
In my opinion, without a lot of page views to back you up you have to argue generic helpfulness of your question from a theoretical standpoint.

@JonnyBoats Re overlapping Qs, I think that's inevitable. As SE grows, we will find more Qs that overlap in scope with other SE sites. It behooves the asker to find the best site to post the question on - the one with the most experts on the topic. But, if the Q is asked on a less optimum site, yet it's still on-topic for that site, it shouldn't be closed as off-topic. We can migrate it to the more appropriate site, but I've found that some people are so stubborn that they'd rather keep it on the original site, despite the fact that migrating it will result in better answers for them. (Cont.)

(Cont.) It's ridiculous and makes no sense to a logical person, but it happens. As for stats.SE, I don't think we can say that all market research Qs will be appropriate for them, but we can judge them on a case by case basis. I've asked the stats mods if a couple of our questions would be acceptable on their site to get a better understanding of their scope. I'll report back here when I get an answer.

+1 @Jin: The 'Sketchy' feel was sketchy.

(My Opinion...) **Name:** Startup are more than just businesses, and 'Startup' should be 'Startups'. **Elevator/Tagline:** Reads as 'business speak' from a faceless corporation, needs to be humanized. **Motto:** Should express a lifestyle that inspires you.

(My Opinion...) **Name:** For ideas, [see the list of sites](http://stackexchange.com/sites). **Elevator/Tagline:** 'Insight' feels weak to me, and lacks the boldness/freshness I relate to startups; 'Insight into startup issues' reads to me as if the reason to first visit the site is to read about other people problems, when the reason people visit the first time is because they have a problem. **Tagline:** 'Tag Line' should be tagline; 'insight' (see Elevator); 'masses' does not express high-quality, which is what people care about. **Motto:** Should express a lifestyle that inspires you.

@JoelFriedlaender That's the way the Stack Exchange engine works. It makes sense for closed questions to resurface to the top after they have been edited. Closed questions can be reopened, and by bringing attention to them after they have been edited it allows the community to take a second look at the question and vote to reopen it if it has been improved to the point that it is now a good fit for the site.

It's not even that Joel doesn't spend much time here but it's also that Dharmesh and Jason have stopped contributing, too. So part of the problem is "Why have they?".

@dnbrv This _used_ to be Dharmesh and Jason's site, but it's not any longer. SE took ownership of the site, and since then Dharmesh and Jason's participation has dropped. I don't know why they stopped participating, but I do know that they are both incredibly busy. Since SE owns this site I would expect Joel to have a bigger incentive and reason to see the site succeed than Dharmesh and Jason.
I thought the site was a joint project between the 3 of them, especially since it still resides on Dharmesh's OnStartups.com domain.

@dnbrv No. This site has a long history. We started as a Dharmesh/Jason (D&J) project. Joel did not own or start the site. D&J licensed the software from Joel (Stack Exchange) and had complete ownership over the site - this was 1.0. Then at some point SE changed their business model and stopped licensing out their software. They either closed down the existing 1.0 sites, or swallowed them into SE. We were transferred to SE. At that point this site no longer belonged to D&J. They negotiated the continued use of the onstartups domain as part of the transfer.

That's why we never went through the Area 51 vetting process. In the early days the quality of this site was much higher. My guess is because the user population was much smaller. My feeling is that after we merged with SE the quality of the site has steadily dropped. See [this answer](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/5) from an SE employee explaining the switch in ownership. And see [my answer here](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/10) that hints at a once high quality site.

Once the site quality improves we can re-evaluate and decide **if** we want to be more lenient.
As mentioned, we don't have the luxury of time. I'll try and find another home for these.

We want to make sure that when people come to this site, they find great answers and relevant, useful questions. In the past we used to evaluate sites ourselves, but it occurred to us that it'd be a lot better to ask the people who are actual experts - that's folks like you. Plus you get a chance to talk to others in the community and get on the same page about the kinds of questions and answers you think work well or not so well.

@JesperMortensen Note that you don't have to review all 10. If you could, that'd be fantastic, but even one reviewed question helps. :) Far as voting on the posts here goes, please base it on both the questions and their answers. If the question is poor but the answers are great, don't hesitate to edit the question to make it better and then upvote the corresponding post. Basically, use your best judgement. If you arrived at a question from a search, would you find it helpful? If so, upvote. If not, downvote. If it's "sort of okay", no need to vote at all. Hope this helps, and thank you!
Everything Anna said, plus: If you're on the fence at all about a question, ask yourself, "If I were a new user on the site, would this question impress or depress me?"

@Christian If your comment is in reference to this meta question being downvoted, please note that voting on meta works differently than on the main site. I think this is actually the opposite of what you want. I believe what you'd like to see is [usa] be made a synonym of [united-states]. In other words, [united-states] would be the primary tag. Is that correct?

@Zuly well, I'm not sure I entirely understand how synonyms work, but I'd think it shouldn't matter which one is primary as long as they both end up pointing to questions tagged with either, am I right?

Yes, by making one tag a synonym of another they will be linked together. So regardless of which one is selected by the user, the primary tag will always show up. However, only one of the two tags will actually be used on the site. So if you have a strong preference for one or the other we need to know, so we can make that one the primary tag (the tag that will always be used). If you don't have a strong preference, that's fine too. We can just pick one. My previous comment was because I assumed you prefered [united-states] over [usa].

@Zuly, I don't really have any preference, I'm just used to united-states, but if usa is the one widely used on onStartups, then probably more people are used to using it. My confusion comes from being primarily on Money@SE where "united-states" is used. I'm guessing anyone else we send from Money@SE to OnStartup will be similarly confused.
I see. I don't really have a preference either. But I do agree that we should make them synonyms to avoid confusion. Let's see what others think. If no one has a preference, we'll just pick one.

@SteveJones, I agree, and I think all of the rules need to be open for discussion. Clearly, some of them are just not working for us. But I think we want to do things thoughtfully and carefully, if we're given the go-ahead to try to fix things. There is some magic in the current rules that prevent these sites from becoming just another Yahoo Answers. It's my opinion that we want to proceed carefully so as to prevent breaking any of the magic. But I'm confident that's possible.

Job One of a site like this should be to attract and retain a community, to promote good questions and useful answers. This has failed due to the rules, so it is obvious that the solution is to relax the rules, along the lines I mentioned previously. Proceeding cautiously will likely fail, as there isn't time to wait and test it. IMHO, better to drop all the restrictions and try to build a meaningful community, then **maybe** tighten the rules later. I'm happy to help, but I suspect that the whole thing is academic anyway, as the site will probably disappear soon. The Gods have spoken...

I don't mind answering some of the questions that get moderated away, but too many of them are asking for expert legal advice, which we shouldn't be doing in any case.

You say that only a few users are taking on moderation tasks. Yet almost without exception, our moderation queues have been empty. (Except recently, when I think a lot of people have become demotivated because of the closure announcement.) You say that the number of users we have won't scale to the amount of drive-by traffic we have. Yet we have a 98% answer rate. Compare that to Stack Overflow, which is 78%. Compare it to Server Fault, which is 81%. Super User is 75%. Mathematics is 83%. How are you *actually measuring* that we don't have a strong enough community?

Area 51 would have us have 5 users with 3K rep. Suppose we change that to 5 *active* users with 3K rep. We have 26 (of 34). Area 51 would have us have 10 users with 2K rep. We have 40 (of 58). Area 51 would have us have 150 200+ users. I didn't manually check *all* of the 200+ rep users, but I got to 150 *active* users after looking at 300 of them (exactly). There are another 430 total after that, so I'd estimate 365 active 200+ rep users. Skipping missing users, we *still* meet the threshold.

You say we "positively can't sustain a democratic moderator election," and I'm not convinced that you're wrong. But I've been paying *very* close attention to this for at least the last year. It's not that we've tried it recently and failed. It's that *we haven't even tried*. How can you be so positively certain that this can't happen unless we make an attempt?

Lastly -- and this is perhaps the most important part -- people in startups are *very* busy people. When a business gets successful (or even if it doesn't) many of them find that they just don't have time to hang out on Q&A sites when a dozen people's jobs are at stake. I think you have to acknowledge that that contributes to at least *some* of the turnover rate. I say, good for them that they got so busy that they couldn't keep participating here.

Wish I could give this +100 as I think this is one of the biggest problems with this site. I stopped learning on this site a long time ago. If you look at a random sampling of questions over the last year you will see that most of the questions are of low quality, and IMHO not the least bit interesting. And that goes for both closed and open questions. You combine the high volume of low quality questions with the lack of community moderation and you end up with a disaster. We've turned into [startups.com](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/10/2692), and they no longer exist.

@rbwhitaker I have some theories of what caused this. I think it all started when our site got merged into Stack Exchange. We started as an independent site, but were later merged into the SE network. That's around the same time that Dharmesh and Jason, the guys who started this community, stopped participating. Becoming part of the SE network increased our traffic and user count, but they were the wrong users. Quality usually decreases with quantity, and that's what happened here.
@ZulyGonzalez, not that it would even be possible, but "un-merging" this site from the rest of Stack Exchange wouldn't fix the problem, would it? I mean, it's kind of a one way street, right?

@rbwhitaker I don't think so. I think that merging with SE started the downward spiral we are in, but I don't think it was because of SE. I see three issues that arose from that: 1) We lost Dharmesh and Jason. I don't know why that happened, it could just have been that they got busy with their startups around the same time we merged with SE. But whatever the reason was, it happened. Their active participation kept the quality of the site up. They attracted true entrepreneurs to the site, not these "tell me the secret to success" wannapreneurs we get now.

2) OnStartups got a lot more visibility and the traffic increased. The problem is that these were the wrong users. One of our users likes to blame the low retention rate to the rules, but that's just not the case. We follow the same rules as the other SE sites, yet we're the one with this problem. Secondly, it doesn't matter whether a new user's question is closed or remains open and is answered. The result is still the same - they leave & never come back. My answer here http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/859 goes into more detail on my opinion on this. The whole thread is worth reading too.

3) The rules changed. IMO, _if_ this is part of the problem, it only accounts for a small portion of the problem. We didn't have these rules when the site first started, but it was a much smaller group. As the site grew, it was necessary to put some rules in place to prevent the site from turning into Yahoo Answers. When we first merged with SE we didn't enforce the SE rules. We started enforcing them **after** the quality of the site went down.
I think that the quality issues this site has is a big problem, but I think that if we had a strong community we could solve them.

For me, the quality is the #1 issue, but the rules (or format) don't help. I tend to believe that startups are easier to learn by example. How did AirBnB solve the chicken and egg problem? I can learn from that. Answering the general question of "how do I get my first customers" is such a vague and open-ended question, I would have to write a encyclopedia. Quora did a great job of gathering those very specific and very insightful questions. The problem with startup questions is that the answers depend on a lot of context, unlike programming questions.

@Zuly, Alain, and Liam, one suggestion, assuming the site doesn't get closed, is to adopt the policy of *aggressively* editing anything that is put on hold, even if it risks not being exactly what the asker is looking for. It may be possible to take so-so questions and make them okay/good questions. This could help improve the quality of new questions *and* still make most people happy. At least they'll get some kind of answer and not feel completely shutdown. Also, that's really what the closing/on hold process is all about is coming together to create great content. Hope this helps!
Sure, but that would be a lot of work from the moderators/editors. Last time I was actively editing, we were no more than 5, not enough for this kind of rewrite. But good idea.

I want to point out an answer I posted: http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/1094/11220 Rather than repost the content. I think a rebrand and rescope would open up your audience and maybe bring in some more professional users that could help balance this site.

I guess you'd put me in the second category (noobs). For startup topics (and business topics) as well, I don't think exact answers exist as long as the questions are formulated as "tell me what I should do, my startup problem is...". As I said before, Quora worked well because they used specific questions ("how did LinkedIn get started"), which have best answers. StackOverflow's pieces of code all have a best solution. We don't. By the way, TheFunded.com had similar problems: the general discussions didn't go very far, but the specific VC ratings were very insightful.
